column2: Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta
Under the umbrella theme of “Devotion & Ritual,” the first Upāsika Day of 2021 was on the topic of Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta, DN 16.

column3: 2021-04-25 Honoring the Buddha The Mahaparinibbana Sutta (Upasika Day 2021).mp3

column6: Thank you for the opportunity to re-take my precepts. I found Ajahn Pasanno's inquiry questions regarding fixed views very useful.
What is the origin of asking a question three times?
Did vibhavatanha arise in any of the monks at the loss of the Buddha? How do we notice vibhavatanha in practice, and what is a wise and compassionate response?
The funeral of a close Wat Pah Nanachat supporter.
What was the name of the rinpoche you referred to earlier?
What was the sutta you mentioned in regard to Ananda's question 'What do we do about women?'
In your guided meditation, devotion to the teachings really touched me. Could you say more about this?
When the Buddha accepted the meal from Cunda, did he know what the consequences would be, and if so, why do you think he did that?
Devotion is what keeps rituals from becoming empty motions.
The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta (DN 16) brings the Buddha's quest full circle.
Throughout the whole teaching (DN 16) there is the sense of the ordinary and the transcendant together all the time.
